title: How many total "Southwest Family Unit Subject and Unaccompanied Alien Children Apprehensions" will U.S. Customs and Border Protection report for the El Centro and San Diego sectors in January 2019?

I looked at the previous FY data (all that were available: FY17 and FY18) and honestly, it didn't help a lot because there simply wasn't enough data to draw conclusions from. From the last available month, November FY19, we know that the number of apprehensions was 7,764, and the limited patterns I could find seemed to indicate that the number would increase to the low 8,000s by January FY19. I gave a relatively high likelihood for the 7,000s range because the patterns I found were weak at best. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

Based on data from JAN 2018 - DEC 2018 from CBP. 7 out of 12 months (~58%) had less than 6000 apprehensions in El Centro and San Diego, while 5 out of 12 months (~42%) had between 6000 and 6999, inclusive. No month had more than 7000.  
I do believe that because of the government shutdown, this number will slightly be up. Not Extremely high numbers but instead be another month with numbers between 6000 and 6999
the amount of family's affected is very high
People will always be trying to cross the border and a majority of Americans are extremely opposed to that idea.
Because no matter how mad people get at the government they aren't gonna stop locking people up at the border.
It was around 7000 and appears to be increasing

An important thing to consider about border crossings is that the amount of migrants fluctuates with apprehensions starting at their lowest in January, building through May (the general peak) and winding down. While this is not always the case, it is the general trend since October, 2011 (FY2012). 	From October to November 2018, the number of apprehensions rose. Since FY2012, this has only happened twice: FY2016, FY2018, and now FY2019. Using these two dates as a benchmark, we can compare the general trend based on this. What I did was calculate the number of FMUA and UAC apprehensions (at the two sites) out of the total number of apprehensions (at the two sites) for each November (2015, 2017, and 2018). In November 2015, FMUA/UAC’s  (at the two sites) were 9.926% of total apprehensions. In Nov. 2017, they were 16.789%. In Nov. 2018, they were 14.972%. 	Next, I calculated the percent drop from Nov to Jan for each of these months. In 2015 it was 27.740%, and in 2017 it was 10.693%. Averaged, this is 19.217% which is the number I used for FY2019. According to this, Jan. 2019 should have approximately 41,891 apprehensions. 	Then, I calculated the average percent of FMUA/UAC (at the two sites) apprehensions out of the total number of apprehensions for January (similar to November). Jan. 2018 was 20.108% and Jan. 2016 was 15.091%. Averaged, this gave us 17.560%. Multiplied by our estimated 41,891 apprehensions, gives us 7,373 UAC apprehensions. 	If we used the lowest percent drop (10.693%) and highest percent of FMUA/UAC (20.108%) for Jan. 2019, we get 9,312, which I used as the upper maximum. The minimum was 5,655. I believe due to the shutdown, the number will be in the upper 6,000’s though could possibly scrape 9,000. I made my percentages around a high 6,000’s number with a few outliers on the end.
Running close to 7500/month. More bad hombres caravans on the way.

Because the Democratic Congress is more interested and jerking their own chain then solving problems. All they can think about is deposing Trump! They need to concentrate on the promises they made to their personal electorate.

11	3190	4574	7764 Correcting forecasting mistake, the display did not make it intuitive that 2018 statistics was actually 2017 and the last two months were on the originally linked page. Given a troop deployment driving up numbers that is supposed to last through January, it seems most likely that the most recent two months will be representative, with perhaps some chance of a drop as the troops draw down.

In Jan 2017, it was a total of 4,723. In Jan 2018, it was a total of 5,223. The low mark was 2,227 in Mar 2017, and the high mark was Nov 2018 (FY19) at 7,764. Since Jul 2018, the average increase has been 480/mo. However, the volatility from month to month is forcing me to spread my bets.

This is a pretty small sample size (we only have two months of data of the two sites) but both months were in the mid 7,000s. So based on nothing at all complicated I think we end up in the same spot.
